Package categoryBase

package categoryBase
Contains the interface Category that provides the necessary structure to build a category. 
In category theory, a category is just a labeled, directed graph with some extra constraints. 
Each of the nodes is called an object, and each of the edges is called a morphism. 
In order for a graph to be considered a category, each object has a morphism pointing at itself, the identity morphism, and morphisms must be able to be composed associatively.
  • Interface Summary
    Interface
    Description
    Category<O>
    Consists of a collection of objects and for each pair of objects A,B a set of morphisms hom(A,B) between them such that: for each object X the set hom(X,X) contains an identity morphism, for each triple of objects X, Y, Z and pair of morphisms f ∈ hom(X,Y) and g ∈ hom(Y,Z), there is a composite morphism (g∘f) ∈ hom(X,Z), for each pair of objects X, Y and morphism f ∈ hom(X,Y), the identity morphisms are left and right units for composition: 1_Y∘f = f = f∘1_X, and for each 4-tuple of objects X, Y, Z, W and triple of morphisms f ∈ hom(X,Y), g ∈ hom(Y,Z), h ∈ hom(Z,W) composition is associative: h∘(g∘f) = (h∘g)∘f.
    Category.Morphism<S,​T>
    An arrow between two objects, the source and the target.  Morphisms are "processes", the possible ways to get from one value to another.  They can be composed: one can follow a process from an initial value to an intermediate value, and then follow a second process to a final value, and consider the two processes together as a single composite process.
    Category.Object<O>
    Elements of the category.  If the category is viewed as a directed graph, they correspond to the nodes.  Both in Java and in category theory, objects are members of a collection.  In Java, it is the collection of values associated to a class.
  • Exception Summary
    Exception
    Description
    IllegalCompositionException
    Thrown if the source of the second morphism doesn't coincide with the target of the first (their objects don't match end-to-end).
